case_name: Baladin Lodhi and others v. State of Uttar Pradesh

facts.text: Two appeals arise out of the same judgment and order of a Division Bench of the Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: These two appeals arise out of the same judgment and order of a Division Bench of the Allahabad High Court, on leave granted by it at the same time that the judgment was delivered.

facts.text: 16 appellants in Criminal Appeal No. 118 of 1954 and one appellant in Criminal Appeal No. 119 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: There are 16 appellants in Criminal Appeal No. 118 of 1954 and only one appellant in 119 of 1954. Both the appeals relate to the occurrence which took place on the morning of the 7th February 1952

facts.text: Occurrence took place on the morning of 7th February 1952 at village Goran, police station Ait, district Jalaun, Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: Both the appeals relate to the occurrence which took place on the morning of the 7th February 1952 at village Goran, police station Ait, in the district of Jalaun of the State of Uttar Pradesh.

facts.text: 57 persons placed on trial before Sessions Judge of Orai on charges under Sections 120B, 148, 201, 302, 325 and 452 all read with Section 149 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: 57 persons were, placed on trial before the learned Sessions Judge of Orai on charges under Sections 120B and 148, Indian Penal Code, as also under Sections 201, 302, 325 and 452, all read with Section 149, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted all accused under Section 120B IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial Judge acquitted all the accused in respect of the charge under Section 120B, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted 36 accused under Sections 148, 201/149 and 302/149 IPC; 9 sentenced to death, others to transportation for life.

anchor.surface_text: He convicted 36 of them under Sections 148, 201/ 149 and 302/149, Indian Penal Code, of whom nine were sentenced to death and the others to transportation for life under Section 302/149, to two years rigorous imprisonment under Section 148

facts.text: One accused Kamoda Chamar convicted under Section 325/149 IPC and sentenced to three years RI.

anchor.surface_text: One more accused named Kamoda Chamar was convicted under Section 325/149, Indian Penal Code and sentenced to three years rigorous imprisonment.

facts.text: 37 out of 57 accused convicted by trial court.

anchor.surface_text: Thus in all 37 out of the 57 accused were convicted and sentenced by the trial court, partly in agreement and partly in disagreement with the assessors.

facts.text: High Court affirmed conviction and death sentence of Baladin Lodhi under Sections 148, 452, 302/149, 201/149 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the High Court dismissed the appeal of Baladin Lodhi, who is the first appellant before us, and affirmed his convictions and sentences under Sections 148, 452, 302/149 and 201/149, Indian Penal Code and accepted the reference, by confirming the sentence of death passed against him

facts.text: High Court acquitted 4 of death-sentenced appellants, reduced sentence to life for others; acquitted 20 appellants; confirmed 17 with sentence modification.

anchor.surface_text: In respect of the other appellants who had been sentenced to death, the High Court allowed the appeal of four of them and acquitted them and in respect of the others allowed their appeal on the question of sentence under Section 302/149 by giving them the lesser sentence of transportation for life.

facts.text: 12 or 13 refugee families from West Punjab rehabilitated in village Goran.

anchor.surface_text: Twelve or thirteen refugee families from the West Punjab were rehabilitated in village Goran which is about 10 miles from Orai town by the direct kachha route and about 25 miles by the road proper.

facts.text: State Government provided refugee families with lands, sites, loans.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government provided those displaced families with lands for cultivation and sites in the village abadi for residential purposes, as also loans for helping them to settle in their new homes.

facts.text: Tension between old residents and new refugee settlers due to competition for lands and sites.

anchor.surface_text: But unfortunately the new-comers were not welcome to the old residents of the village because they were looked upon as competitors for house sites and culturable lands of the village.

facts.text: Incident on 4th February 1952 between Diwan Singh, Mangal Singh (refugees) and Vir Singh Lodhi, Shambhu Lodhi; grievous hurt to Shambhu, simple injuries to refugees. Admitted by both parties.

anchor.surface_text: On that date Vir Singh alias Vir Lodhi was alleged to have secured the services of one Shambhu Lodhi... It is admitted by both parties that an incident took place between Diwan Singh and Mangal Singh...

facts.text: 13 male refugees including Mool Singh, Mela Singh, Sant Singh, Ravel Singh went to Orai on 5th February 1952 to report to authorities.

anchor.surface_text: As the refugees found the attitude of the local police hostile to them, 13 male members of the refugee families including Mool Singh, Mela Singh, Sant Singh and Ravel Singh... came to Orai on the morning of the 5th February 1952

facts.text: Villagers assembled at Parichhat Lodhi's house on evening of 6th February 1952 and resolved to kill male members of refugee families.

anchor.surface_text: The villagers are said to have assembled at the house of Parichhat Lodhi... after having come to know that most of the male members of the refugee families had gone to the district headquarters... resolved to kill all the male members

facts.text: Six refugees - Mool Singh, Mela Singh, Ravel Singh s/o Mangal, Sant Singh, Kastura Singh, Harbans Singh - went back to village Goran on morning of 7th February 1952 at sunrise.

anchor.surface_text: It was decided that six of the refugees, namely, Mool Singh, Mela Singh, Ravel Singh son of Mangal Singh, Sant Singh, Kastura Singh and Harbans Singh should go back to the village to rescue their families.

facts.text: Crowd of 80-100 armed persons surrounded Mangal Singh's house; Narain Das Lodhi, Baladin Lodhi and others shot Mela Singh, Mool Singh, Ravel Singh on first floor.

anchor.surface_text: suddenly a crowd of 80 to 100 persons surrounded the said Mangal Singhs house armed with axes, spears, daggers, guns, etc. Narain Das Lodhi and Baladin Lodhi along with 15 to 20 other Lodhis appeared on the first floor... shot down those three persons.

facts.text: Mela Singh hidden in grain room by Bhagwanti, later dragged out by Raja Ram, Mahabir; assaulted by Jangi with axe, Uma Charan with sword.

anchor.surface_text: As soon as Mela Singh received two gunshot wounds... he was picked up by Smt. Bhagwanti... and was hidden in the grain room... Mela Singh who had been concealed... was said to have been dragged out by Raja Ram and Mahabir... assaulted by Jangi Lodhi... with axes, and by Uma Charan... with a sword

facts.text: Dead bodies of six victims loaded on carts of Manna Teli and Vira Lodhi, taken to tank, sprinkled with kerosene, burnt to ashes.

anchor.surface_text: The dead bodies of all those six helpless victims were then dragged to the front of Manna Telis house. Two bullock carts, one belonging to and driven by Manna Teli... and the other belonging to and driven by Vira Lodhi... loaded each with three of the dead bodies... set fire to the joint pyre

facts.text: Four eyewitnesses: Mst. Paiyyan Devi (widow Mela Singh), Mst. Shanti Devi (widow Mool Singh), Mst. Parvati (widow Sant Singh), Mst. Bhagwanti (wife Mangal Singh, mother Ravel Singh).

anchor.surface_text: Such was the ghastly tragedy which is said to have been witnessed by four of the female inmates... namely, Mst. Paiyyan Devi P.W. 18, Mst. Shanti Devi P.W. 21, and Mst. Parvati P. W. 22... and the fourth Mst. Bhagwanti P.W. 20

facts.text: Village chowkidar Ramola lodged information at 5 p.m. on 7th February 1952 that all was quiet in village.

anchor.surface_text: the village chowkidar Ramola, one of the appellants, had lodged an information at the police station that all was quiet in the village. As will presently appear, it was the quiet of a deserted village after the holocaust

facts.text: Police investigation unsatisfactory; local police hostile to refugees; Sub-Inspector Raj Bahadur Singh twisted case to suggest night occurrence.

anchor.surface_text: A remarkable feature of the case... is the unsatisfactory manner in which the police investigation took place. It appears that the local police... were not only apathetic but definitely hostile to the refugees.

facts.text: High Court delivered judgment on 10th September 1954 and granted leave to appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: After examining in great detail the evidence against each individual accused the High Court delivered its judgment on the 10th September 1954 and presumably at the request of counsel... recorded... Leave to appeal to Supreme Court is granted.

facts.text: Supreme Court held certificate under Article 134(1)(c) not properly granted, but granted special leave under Article 136.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, following our previous decision, we are unable to regard this appeal as properly certified... But that still leaves us a discretion to examine whether this is a fit case for us to exercise our special powers under Article 136(1)

facts.text: Supreme Court acquitted Thakur Das, Ishwari Prasad, Mulloo, Jagdish for lack of specific overt acts.

anchor.surface_text: It remains to consider the cases of Thakur Das, Ishwari Prasad, Mulloo and Jagdish. These four appellants had not been assigned any particular part... They will, therefore, be given the benefit of the doubt and acquitted.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld convictions of Baladin Lodhi, Raja Ram, Uma Charan, Mahabir, Narain Das, Ramola, Vir Singh, Mannu Teli, Jangi.

anchor.surface_text: In that category are Baladin Lodhi, Parichhat... They have therefore been rightly convicted... His conviction and sentence must therefore be upheld... His appeal must therefore also stand dismissed.

issues.text: Whether the certificate granted by the High Court under Article 134(1)(c) of the Constitution is valid and the appeal is maintainable thereunder?

anchor.surface_text: At the outset the learned counsel for the State of Uttar Pradesh (the respondent) raised a preliminary objection to the hearing of the appeal on the ground that the certificate granted in the terms quoted above is not in full compliance with the provisions of Article 134(1)(c) of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether this is a fit case for the Supreme Court to exercise its special powers under Article 136(1)?

anchor.surface_text: But that still leaves us a discretion to examine whether this is a fit case for us to exercise our special powers under Article 136(1)

issues.text: Whether the courts below were in error in relying upon the evidence of the four eye-witnesses when their statements in court were at variance with their statements as recorded by the investigating Sub-Inspector?

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the appellants raised four questions before us, namely, 1 that the courts below were in error in relying upon the evidence of the four eye-witnesses aforesaid when their statements in court were at variance with their statements as recorded by the investigating Sub-Inspector

issues.text: Whether the courts below were in error in convicting and sentencing the appellants on the testimony of those four eye-witnesses when their evidence had not been acted upon in respect of the other accused who had been acquitted by the courts below?

anchor.surface_text: 2 that the courts below were in error in convicting and sentencing the appellants on the testimony of those four eye-witnesses when their evidence had not been acted upon in respect of the other accused who had been acquitted by the courts below

issues.text: Whether the evidence of those four eye-witnesses having been disbelieved by the lower appellate court particularly in respect of some accused to whom specific parts had been attributed should have been accepted in respect of those accused to whom no such parts had been assigned?

anchor.surface_text: 3 that the evidence of those four eye-witnesses having been disbelieved by the lower appellate court, particularly in respect of some of those accused persons to whom they had attributed specific parts, should, not have been accepted in respect of those accused to whom no such parts had been assigned

issues.text: Whether the courts below erred in law in convicting accused persons against whom no specific overt acts had been deposed to and whose mere presence in the assembly had been penalized?

anchor.surface_text: 4 that the courts below had erred in law in convicting those accused persons against whom no specific parts had been deposed to and whose mere presence, in the assembly had been penalized.

arguments.claim: The certificate granted by the High Court under Article 134(1)(c) is not in full compliance with the provisions as it lacks evidence of judicial discretion applied to each accused.

anchor.surface_text: At the outset the learned counsel for the State of Uttar Pradesh (the respondent) raised a preliminary objection to the hearing of the appeal on the ground that the certificate granted in the terms quoted above is not in full compliance with the provisions of Article 134(1)(c) of the Constitution.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: entencing the appellants on the testimony of those four eye-witnesses when their evidence had number been acted upon in respect of the other accused w

arguments.court_reasoning: No reasons apparent on face of order; High Court did not realize responsibility under Art 134(1)(c); follows Nar Singh precedent.

arguments.claim: The High Court granted the certificate in exercise of powers under Rule 28 of Chapter 23 of Allahabad High Court Rules, requiring prayer at judgment delivery, so it should be assumed the High Court directed attention to each accused.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued on behalf of the appellants that the High Court granted the certificate in exercise of its powers contained in Rule 28 of Chapter 23 of the Rules of the Allahabad High Court which required that the counsel for the appellant should pray for the leave at the time the judgment of the High Court is delivered.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: been acted upon in respect of the other accused who had been acquitted by the companyrts below  3  that the evidence of those four eye-witnesses havi

arguments.court_reasoning: Insufficient; certificate must show judicial discretion with reasons apparent; mechanical grant invalid per Nar Singh.

arguments.claim: Certificate under Art 134(1)(c) invalid as no reasons given, no judicial discretion exercised; 'certifies' requires mind applied and reasons on face.

anchor.surface_text: We have not to determine whether that is so. That case lays down three propositions-- 1 that the mere grant of a certificate does not prevent this Court from determining whether it was rightly granted...

arguments.claim: Courts below erred in relying on evidence of four eye-witnesses as their court statements varied with statements recorded by investigating Sub-Inspector.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the appellants raised four questions before us, namely, 1 that the courts below were in error in relying upon the evidence of the four eye-witnesses aforesaid when their statements in court were at variance with their statements as recorded by the investigating Sub-Inspector

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the certificate prayed for should be granted in respect of each and every accused companyvicted by it. It was argued on behalf of the appellants that

arguments.court_reasoning: Police records unreliable, deliberately perfunctory/dishonest; court testimony to be weighed independently; prior statements not substantive evidence.

arguments.claim: Courts below erred in convicting appellants on testimony of four eye-witnesses when their evidence not acted upon for other accused acquitted by courts below.

anchor.surface_text: 2 that the courts below were in error in convicting and sentencing the appellants on the testimony of those four eye-witnesses when their evidence had not been acted upon in respect of the other accused who had been acquitted by the courts below

court_response_anchor.surface_text: y very much in the lime-light on that morning. In view of his leading activities against the refugee families, it is number improbable that he took a

arguments.court_reasoning: Each accused case examined individually; acquittal of some does not discredit evidence for those with specific overt acts.

arguments.claim: Evidence of four eye-witnesses disbelieved by lower appellate court for some accused with specific parts attributed should not be accepted for accused with no specific parts.

anchor.surface_text: 3 that the evidence of those four eye-witnesses having been disbelieved by the lower appellate court, particularly in respect of some of those accused persons to whom they had attributed specific parts, should, not have been accepted in respect of those accused to whom no such parts had been assigned

court_response_anchor.surface_text: y very much in the lime-light on that morning. In view of his leading activities against the refugee families, it is number improbable that he took a

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court erred by relying on tainted police records; court testimony reliable when corroborated; specific acts determine liability individually.

arguments.claim: Courts below erred in law in convicting accused without specific overt acts deposed to, penalizing mere presence in assembly.

anchor.surface_text: 4 that the courts below had erred in law in convicting those accused persons against whom no specific overt acts had been deposed to and whose mere presence, in the assembly had been penalized.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: y very much in the lime-light on that morning. In view of his leading activities against the refugee families, it is number improbable that he took a

arguments.court_reasoning: Accepted for those without overt acts (acquitted Thakur Das etc.); rejected for those with specific roles (upheld Baladin etc.).

arguments.claim: Mere presence in assembly does not make one member of unlawful assembly unless overt act/omission shown or falls under s142 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that mere presence in an assembly does not make such a person a member of an unlawful assembly unless it is shown that he had done something or omitted to do something which would make him a member of an unlawful assembly,

arguments.claim: High Court erred by acquitting accused whose names not in police record, despite condemning record as unreliable; rejected reliable court testimony.

anchor.surface_text: Having held that the four eye-witnesses were on the whole reliable and that the record of their statements made by the investigating Sub-Inspector was not honest and faithful, the High Court fell into the error of acquitting all those accused persons, appellants before it, whose names did not find a place in the record made by that police officer.

arguments.claim: Police statements during investigation not substantive evidence; valuable only for contradictions/veracity; if record tainted/unreliable, diminished value.

anchor.surface_text: statements made during police investigation are not substantive evidence. Hence the record made by a police investigating officer has to be considered by the court only with a view to weighing the evidence actually adduced in court.

arguments.claim: No conspiracy under s120B proved despite belief in pre-occurrence meeting.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial Judge acquitted all the accused in respect of the charge under Section 120B, Indian Penal Code.

arguments.claim: Four eye-witnesses truthful, corroborate on material points; Sub-Inspector did not faithfully record statements, distorted to favour accused.

anchor.surface_text: In the course of his judgment the learned trial Judge found that the four women witnesses who figured as the only eye-witnesses of the occurrence were on the whole truthful witnesses who corroborate one another on all material questions that their statements as recorded by the sub-Inspector, Raj Bahadur Singh, was not a faithful record

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the certificate prayed for should be granted in respect of each and every accused companyvicted by it. It was argued on behalf of the appellants that

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agrees witnesses reliable, police records tainted.

arguments.claim: Defence complete denial of occurrence and deaths; implication due to enmity with refugees; if occurred, in night darkness by unknown persons.

anchor.surface_text: The defence was a complete denial of all knowledge of the occurrence and the alleged death of all the six male refugees who had travelled on the night between the 6th and 7th February from Orai to the village. The accused persons ascribed their implication in the occurrence to various kinds of enmity between them and the refugee families.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: embers. After talking over the situation at both ends and exchanging information, three of them, namely, Mela Singh, Ravel Singh and Mool Singh were t

arguments.court_reasoning: Eye-witness testimony reliable; specific evidence of daylight occurrence and roles.

arguments.claim: Specific overt acts assign liability under s149 IPC for those like Baladin Lodhi (shooting), Raja Ram (dragging, axe), etc.; mere spectators acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: There cannot be the least doubt that those who had trespassed into the first floor of the house of Mangal Singh and killed those three refugees who had gone upstairs to have their breakfast were certainly up to their neck in the conspiracy and were thus very active members of the unlawful assembly. In that category are Baladin Lodhi, Parichhat...

holdings.text: The certificate granted by the High Court under Article 134(1)(c) is invalid as it lacks reasons indicating judicial discretion and appears mechanical.

anchor.surface_text: We have not to determine whether that is so. That case lays down three propositions-- 1 that the mere grant of a certificate does not prevent this Court from determining whether it was rightly granted... Accordingly, following our previous decision, we are unable to regard this appeal as properly certified

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Nar Singh precedent requiring reasons apparent on face for certification; no such reasons here, High Court did not apply mind.

holdings.text: This is a fit case for exercising special powers under Article 136(1) due to substantial question on mere presence under s149 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: But that still leaves us a discretion to examine whether this is a fit case for us to exercise our special powers under Article 136(1), and that we now proceed to do.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fourth ground raises important legal issue warranting interference despite factual grounds not sufficient.

holdings.text: Courts below did not err in relying on eye-witness testimony despite variances with police statements, as police records were deliberately perfunctory and dishonest.

anchor.surface_text: statements made during police investigation are not substantive evidence. Hence the record made by a police investigating officer has to be considered by the court only with a view to weighing the evidence actually adduced in court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Police statements not substantive evidence; tainted records lose value; court testimony weighed independently.

holdings.text: No error in convicting appellants on eye-witness testimony while acquitting others, as each accused assessed individually based on specific evidence.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that mere presence in an assembly does not make such a person a member of an unlawful assembly unless it is shown that he had done something...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence evaluated per accused; acquittal of some does not discredit reliable testimony against others with overt acts.

holdings.text: High Court erred by rejecting court testimony based on tainted police records for accused not named therein; testimony reliable when corroborated.

anchor.surface_text: Having held that the four eye-witnesses were on the whole reliable and that the record of their statements made by the investigating Sub-Inspector was not honest...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Police record unreliable; cannot use to discard consistent court evidence; High Court inconsistency corrected.

holdings.text: Mere presence in unlawful assembly insufficient for liability under s149 IPC; requires overt act or omission making one member, unless under s142 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that mere presence in an assembly does not make such a person a member of an unlawful assembly unless it is shown that he had done something or omitted to do something which would make him a member of an unlawful assembly,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-settled law applied; acquitted those without specific acts, upheld for active participants.

holdings.text: Convictions under ss 148, 302/149, 201/149, 452 IPC upheld for Baladin Lodhi, Parichhat s/o Lallu, Ajodhia Lodhi, Parichhat s/o Sadhoo as active in shooting victims.

anchor.surface_text: There cannot be the least doubt that those who had trespassed into the first floor of the house of Mangal Singh and killed those three refugees... were certainly up to their neck in the conspiracy... They have therefore been rightly convicted

holdings.reasoning_summary: Specific overt acts (trespass, shooting) prove membership and common object prosecution.

holdings.text: Convictions of Raja Ram under ss 148, 201/149, 302/149, 452 upheld; active role in dragging and axing Mela Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Raja Ram... He is said to have dragged Mela Singh out of the grain room... given an axe blow... His conviction and sentence must therefore be upheld.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinct overt acts and history of hostility confirm participation.

holdings.text: Convictions of Uma Charan under ss 148, 302/149, 201/149 upheld; sword blow to Mela Singh and burning bodies.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Uma Charan... hit Mela Singh on the head with a sword... took part in the burning... His appeal must therefore also stand dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Leading part in assault and evidence disposal furthers common object.

holdings.text: Convictions of Mahabir under ss 148, 302/149, 201/149, 452 upheld; dragged bodies and Mela Singh.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant Mahabir Pershad... dragged out Mela Singh... present at disposal of dead bodies... His appeal must therefore also stand dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Continuous presence and specific dragging acts from start to end.

holdings.text: Convictions of Narain Das under ss 148, 302/149, 201/149 upheld; incited mob.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant Narain Das... assigned the specific part of inciting the mob... courts below were therefore fully justified... His appeal must also stand dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Specific incitement and proximity negate mere presence.

holdings.text: Convictions of Ramola under ss 148, 302/149, 201/149 upheld; false report to conceal crime.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant Ramola... false report at the police station was only meant to shield... Courts below were therefore justified in convicting him... His appeal must also stand dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dereliction (false report) aids common object of concealment.

holdings.text: Convictions of Vir Singh upheld; imported Shambhu, carted bodies, seen on roof.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant Vir Singh... set the ball rolling... taken three of the dead bodies in his cart... His appeal was also rightly dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Initiated events and specific disposal role.

holdings.text: Convictions of Mannu Teli upheld; carted bodies to pyre.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant Mannu Teli... carrying three of the dead bodies on his cart... His appeal was also rightly dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Specific carting act furthers destruction of evidence.

holdings.text: Convictions of Jangi under ss 148, 302/149, 201/149 upheld; axed Mela Singh.

anchor.surface_text: It remains to consider the case of the only appellant Jangi... struck Mela Singh... with an axe... Hence it cannot be said that he was a mere sightseer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Eye-witness identification and Sessions finding as ring-leader; police record omission irrelevant.

holdings.text: Thakur Das, Ishwari Prasad, Mulloo, Jagdish acquitted under s302/149 etc. for lack of specific overt acts.

anchor.surface_text: These four appellants had not been assigned any particular part... no overt act has been attributed to them... They will, therefore, be given the benefit of the doubt and acquitted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of acts beyond possible spectatorship; benefit of doubt.

precedents.citation: Nar Singh V. State of U.P.,

anchor.surface_text: the decision of this Court in Nar Singh V. State of U.P., . We have no to determine whether that is so. That case lays down three propositions-- 1 that the mere grant of a certificate does number prevent this Court from determining whether it was rightly granted and whether the companyditions pre-requisite to the grant are satisfied 2 that the only companydition is the exercise or a judicial discretion by the High Court 3 that being a judicial discretion, it must be exercised along well established lines governing an exercise of judicial discretion and 4 if the discretion is properly exercised on well established and proper lines, then, as in all cases where an exercise of discretion is involved, there would be numberinterference except on very strong grounds.

precedents.case_name: Nar Singh v. State of U.P.
precedents.cited_proposition: principles governing the grant of certificate under Article 134(1)(c) of the Constitution, including that the High Court must exercise judicial discretion with reasons apparent on the face of the order
precedents.cited_holding: lays down propositions that: (1) mere grant of certificate does not prevent Supreme Court from scrutinizing it; (2) condition is exercise of judicial discretion; (3) discretion must follow established lines; (4) no interference unless strong grounds

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals of Thakur Das, Ishwari Prasad, Mulloo and Jagdish allowed and they acquitted; appeals of remaining 13 appellants dismissed with convictions and sentences under Sections 148, 302/149, 201/149, 452 IPC etc. upheld as modified by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We have not to determine whether that is so. That case lays down three propositions-- 1 that the mere grant of a certificate does not prevent this Court from determining whether it was rightly granted... Accordingly, following our previous decision, we are unable to regard this appeal as properly certified
In the result, the appeal of Thakur Das, Ishwari Prasad, Mulloo and Jagdish is allowed.

anchor.surface_text: statements made during police investigation are not substantive evidence. Hence the record made by a police investigating officer has to be considered by the court only with a view to weighing the evidence actually adduced in court.
In the result, the appeal of Thakur Das, Ishwari Prasad, Mulloo and Jagdish is allowed.
It is well settled that mere presence in an assembly does not make such a person a member of an unlawful assembly unless it is shown that he had done something...
In the result, the appeal of Thakur Das, Ishwari Prasad, Mulloo and Jagdish is allowed.
Having held that the four eye-witnesses were on the whole reliable and that the record of their statements made by the investigating Sub-Inspector was not honest...
